PT J
AN ZOOR15104025297
DT Article
TI Taxonomy of Probolodus Eigenmann, 1911 (Characiformes: Characidae) with
   description of two new species, and comments about the phylogenetic
   relationships and biogeography of the genus.
AU Santos, Osmar (osmysantos@yahoo.com.br) 
   Castro, Ricardo M.C.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 12
IS 2
PS 403-418
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Probolodus is a genus of tetras distributed along the coastal basins of
   southeastern Brazil, from Espirito Santo on the north, to Sao Paulo
   states. It was proposed by Eigenmann in 1911, to include the single
   species P. heterostomus. However, examining of material recently
   collected we identified two new species: P. oyakawai, new species, from
   the rio Ribeira de Iguape basin, and P. sazimai, new species, from the
   rio Itapemirim (Espirito Santo), and drainages of the rio Doce basin
   (Espirito Santo and Minas Gerais states). Therefore, the distribution of
   P. heterostomus was restricted to the rio Paraiba do Sul basin,
   southeastern Brazil. The genus Probolodus was redefined based on
   osteological characters, in particular details of oral dentition.
   Probolodus heterostomus differs from its congeners by a combination of
   meristic and osteological characters. An identification key for the
   species of the genus is presented. The possible evolutionary
   relationships of Probolodus with other characids, especially some
   lepidophagous taxa are discussed. Regarding the biogeography of the
   group, some geological events are hypothesized as responsible for the
   cladogenetic events among species of the genus.

EM osmysantos@yahoo.com.br

   P. 406].

AN ZOOR15104025300
DT Article
TI A new stem fossil characid (Teleostei: Ostariophysi) from the
   Eocene-Oligocene of southeastern Brazil.
AU Weiss, Fernanda E. (fewebr@yahoo.com.br) 
   Malabarba, Maria Claudia
   Malabarba, Luiz R.
SO Neotropical Ichthyology
VL 12
IS 2
PS 439-450
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new characiform is herein described from the Eocene-Oligocene
   sediments exposed in the Aiuruoca basin, in southern Minas Gerais State,
   Brazil. Recently, two other characid species were described for this
   same fossil level: [dagger]Paleotetra aiuruoca and [dagger]Paleotetra
   entrecorregos. The holotype of this new characiform is represented by an
   articulated specimen preserved as part and counterpart, in which the
   most anterior part of the head is missing, including the jaws. Despite
   the lack of the diagnostic characters from the snout, a unique
   combination of characters allows its differentiation from other
   Neotropical characiforms, raising a new genus and species:
   [dagger]Bryconetes enigmaticus. Among these characters are: the presence
   of a supraorbital, dentary with inflated pentacuspidate teeth arranged
   in a single row, infraorbital 3 expanded and ornamented with
   punctuations and grooves, a large anal fin with iii+22-23 rays, and the
   caudal fin with 11 ventral procurrent rays of which the anteriormost are
   fused in laminar bones. A phylogenetic analysis using morphological data
   was performed and recovered [dagger]Bryconetes enigmaticus as a stem
   group to characiforms lacking a supraorbital. Based on the results of
   this analysis, a discussion of the potential relationships of the new
   taxon with other characiforms is presented.

   Av Bento Goncalves 9500, Porto Alegre, RS, BR-91501970 BC, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM fewebr@yahoo.com.br
RI Malabarba, Luiz R/I-3225-2012
OI Malabarba, Luiz R/0000-0002-9607-3735

DT Article
TI TAXONOMY AND DISTRIBUTION OF NARROW-MOUTH FROGS OF THE GENUS Microhyla
   TSCHUDI, 1838 (ANURA: MICROHYLIDAE) FROM VIETNAM WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF
   FIVE NEW SPECIES.
AU Poyarkov, Nikolay A., Jr
   Vassilieva, Anna B.
   Orlov, Nikolai L.
   Galoyan, Eduard A.
   Tran Thi Anh Dao
   Duong Thi Thuy Le
   Kretova, Valentina D.
   Geissler, Peter
SO Russian Journal of Herpetology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 89-148
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We review the taxonomy and distribution of Microhyla Tschudi, 1838
   (Anura: Microhylidae) species from Vietnam, with a special regional
   focus on the southern parts of the Annamite mountain range (Kon Turn and
   Langbian Plateaus, Tay Nguyen highlands) and its foothills. Recent field
   work in this area revealed specimens of five yet un-described species,
   which are differentiated from all congeners by a combination of
   morphological traits: Microhyla pineticola sp. nov. from Lam Dong and
   Dak Lak provinces; Microhyla pulchella sp. nov. from Lam Dong Province;
   Microhyla minuta sp. nov. from Dong Nai Province; Microhyla darevskii
   sp. nov. from Kon Turn Province; and Microhyla arboricola sp. nov. from
   Dak Lak and Khanh Hoa provinces. Microhyla annamensis Smith, 1923 is
   redescribed based on recently collected material. The intrageneric
   systematic relationships of the new species are discussed. We provide
   first larval descriptions for four of the new species as well as for
   Microhyla annamensis Smith 1923. Notes on the breeding ecology and
   natural history of all above mentioned species are compiled for the
   first time. With Microhyla minuta sp. nov. and Microhyla arboricola sp.
   nov. we describe the probably smallest tetrapods currently known from
   mainland Southeast Asia. The latter species also represents the second
   record of a phytotelm breeder within the genus Microhyla. A key to the
   currently known Vietnamese species of Microhyla is provided.

AB A revision of taxonomic structure of Ploynocephalus arabicus Anderson,
   1984 complex is presented. Phrynocephalus nejdensis Haas, 1957 and
   Phrynocephalus macropeltis Haas, 1957 are considered as valid species,
   based on the morphological and genetic difference. A new species from
   south-western Iran, the Ahvaz plains is described. It differs
   morphologically from all other representatives of the species Ph.
   arabicus complex by body and tail proportions, dorsal coloration,
   undertail coloration and genetic characters.

TI A swarm of whiteflies-the first record of gregarious behavior from

AB A new whitefly Snotra christelae gen. et sp. n. is characterized,
   illustrated, and described from the Baltic amber. It represents the
   first record of gregarious behavior of Aleyrodinae (Aleyrodidae)
   whiteflies in fossil state. Implications of this finding on

   evolutionary traits of the group are discussed.

DT Article
TI Revision of Plumulites ruskini Lamont, and new data from the Silurian of
   the Pentland Hills, Scotland.
AU Candela, Yves (y.candela@nms.ac.uk) 
   Crighton, William R.B.
SO Scottish Journal of Geology
VL 51
IS 1
PS 31-42
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Disarticulated sclerites of plumulitid machaeridians were collected from
   the Wether Law Linn Formation (Telychian) in the Pentland Hills,
   Scotland. The specimens are described and compared to specimens
   collected earlier from the same horizon and locality. Other specimens
   from the same horizon, assigned in previous works to Turrilepas haswelli
   then to Plumulites sp., are figured here for the first time. The
   micro-ornament on plumulitid machaeridians is also documented for the
   first time. Seven sclerite types are identified and tentatively
   associated into scleritomes. The collection from the Pentland Hills is
   compared with other Ordovician and Silurian taxa from various Scottish
   localities, and this comparative study indicates that the present
   collection may constitute a new taxon. Nevertheless, complete
   individuals have to be collected to warrant a confident taxonomic
   identification.
C1 Candela, Yves; Natl Museums Scotland, Dept Nat Sci, Chambers St,
   Edinburgh, Midlothian, EH1 1JF, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM y.candela@nms.ac.uk

AN ZOOR15110065841
DT Article
TI Ichthyosaurs from the Jurassic of Skye, Scotland.
AU Brusatte, Stephen L. (Stephen.Brusatte@ed.ac.uk) 
   Young, Mark T.
   Challands, Thomas J.
   Clark, Neil D.L.
   Fischer, Valentin
   Fraser, Nicholas C.
   Liston, Jeff J.
   MacFadyen, Colin C.J.
   Ross, Dugald A.
   Walsh, Stig
   Wilkinson, Mark
SO Scottish Journal of Geology
VL 51
IS 1
PS 43-55
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fossils of Mesozoic vertebrates are rare in Scotland, particularly
   specimens of marine reptiles such as plesiosaurs and ichthyosaurs. We
   describe a suite of ichthyosaur fossils from the Early to Middle
   Jurassic of Skye, which to our knowledge are the first ichthyosaurs from
   Scotland to be described and figured in detail. These fossils span
   approximately 30 million years, from the Sinemurian to the Bathonian,
   and indicate that ichthyosaurs were a major component of Scottish marine
   faunas during this time. The specimens include isolated teeth that could
   represent the most northerly known occurrences of the widespread
   Sinemurian species Ichthyosaurus communis, a characteristic component of
   the famous Lyme Regis faunas of England, suggesting that such faunas
   were also present in Scotland during the Early Jurassic. An associated
   humerus and vertebrae from Toarcian-Bajocian-aged deposits are named as
   a new genus and species of basal neoichthyosaurian, Dearcmhara
   shawcrossi. The taxonomic affinities of this taxon, which comes from a
   critical but poorly sampled interval in the fossil record, suggest that
   non-ophthalmosaurid neoichthyosaurians dominated European assemblages
   around the Early-Middle Jurassic boundary, and were later replaced by
   ophthalmosaurids, whose radiation likely took place outside Europe. Many
   of these specimens were collected by amateurs and donated to museum
   collections, a co-operative relationship essential to the preservation
   of Scotland's fossil heritage.
C1 Brusatte, Stephen L.; Univ Edinburgh, Sch Geosci, Kings Bldg,James
   Hutton Rd, Edinburgh, Midlothian, EH9 3FE, United Kingdom, United
   Kingdom.
EM Stephen.Brusatte@ed.ac.uk
SC Zoology
SN 0036-9276
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Dearcmhara [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Dearcmhara shawcrossi [Scotland /  / new species] [Jurassic /  / ]. 
   Ichthyosaurus [Scotland / Hebrides, Skye / new record; stratigraphical
   distribution; systematics] [Jurassic / Early to Middle Jurassic / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Euryapsida, Ichthyosauria
OR Dearcmhara (Ichthyosauria): [Gen nov, Of Neoichthyosauria, Type species
   Dearcmhara shawcrossi, p. 50, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Dearcmhara shawcrossi (Ichthyosauria): [Sp nov, Scotland, Jurassic, P.
   50; Fossil]. 
   Ichthyosaurus (Ichthyosauria): [Fossil; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15110065841

DT Article
TI New Record of the mexican hairy porcupine Sphiggurus mexicanus (Rodendia
   [Rodentia]: Erethizontidae) in the Eastern Sierra of Mexico.
FT Registro Notable del Puercoespin Arboricola Sphiggurus mexicanus
   (Rodendia: Erethizontidae) en la Sierra Madre Oriental, Mexico.
AU Lira-Torres, Ivan (ilira_12@hotmail.com)

   Ojeda-Ramirez, Deyanira
   Gomez de Anda, Fabian R.
SO THERYA
VL 5
IS 1
PS 271-275
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 2
AB Introduction: The Mexican hairy porcupine Sphiggurus mexicanus
   (Rodentia: Erethizontidae) has been poorly studied in Mexico and is
   considered threatened according to NOM-059-ECOL-2010 (Mexican list of
   endangered species). Habitat loss due to fragmentation is a major
   problem for this species throughout its geographic range. Methodology:
   An adult female Mexican hairy porcupine (Sphiggurus mexicanus) in good
   health was donated to the Nicolas Bravo Zoo in Tulancingo City, state of
   Hidalgo, Mexico, in June 2013. Prior to admission to the zoo, the
   specimen was quarantined in the veterinary school of the Universidad
   Autonoma del Estado de Hidalgo (UAEH). Results: The porcupine was
   successfully fed a diet based on alfalfa, mango, mamey (Pouteria
   sapota), avocado and squash. We found two species of ectoparasites on
   the porcupine, Amblyomma longirostre and Trichodectes sp. The specimen
   of Sphiggurus mexicanus was collected at 20.29077[degree]N,
   -98.11047[degree] W, near the Pahuatlan River, on the border between the
   states of Puebla and Hidalgo, in the Eastern Sierra of Mexico.
   Discussion: This location record is new and is important in that it
   confirms and documents the presence of the Mexican hairy porcupine
   Sphiggurus mexicanus, with geographical coordinates, in the Eastern
   Sierra of Mexico. Habitat connection to the previously known locality 70
   km away in the area of Tuzamapan de Galeana, Puebla is not clear.
C1 Lira-Torres, Ivan; Univ Autonoma Estado Hidalgo, Inst Ciencias
   Agropecuarias, Rancho Univ Av Univ Km 1, Tulancingo, Hidalgo, 43600,
   Mexico, Mexico.
EM ilira_12@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 2007-3364
BD Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Sphiggurus mexicanus [Mexico / Sierra Madre, east / New record]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Erethizontidae
OR Sphiggurus mexicanus (Erethizontidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15208050235
DT Article
TI New records of fleas on Virginia opossums Didelphis virginiana (Kerr
   1792) in Queretaro, Mexico.
FT Nuevos registros de pulgas de tlacuaches Didelphis virginiana (Kerr
   1792) en Queretaro, Mexico.
AU Hernandez-Camacho, Norma (norma.hernandez@uaq.mx) 
   Vergara-Pineda, Santiago
   Acosta-Gutierrez, Roxana
   Jones, Robert W.
SO THERYA
VL 5
IS 1
PS 347-353
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Introduction: The opossum Didelphis virginiana (Kerr 1792) is one of the
   eight species of marsupials that live in the northern region of America
   and is widely distributed in Mexico. There is a large literature in
   North America of studies on this species, including its ectoparasites.
   But in Mexico studies are scarce, and so we decided to investigate the
   opossum ectoparasite species richness in a suburban landscape in
   Queretaro, Mexico. Methods: During January to May of 2010, we used 12
   tomahawk traps to capture opossums. Each animal was immobilized with
   tiletilamina, and during recumbence we examined the opossums for
   ectoparasites. Fleas were collected in vials with 70% alcohol, then
   dehydrataded in 100% alcohol, and clarified with lactic acid for further
   identification. Results: We found four flea species on the trapped
   opossums (n = 26), 14 males, 12 females. The species were
   Ctenocephalides felis, Euhoplopsyllus glacialis affinnis, Polygenis
   martinezbaezi and Polygenis sp. Two of these species are considered as
   new records for this marsupial host in Mexico, although these species
   have been recorded previously in this species in the United States and
   in other marsupial species in Mexico. Discussion: These fleas are new
   records for the Mexican opossum parasite fauna. This study, although
   initially didactic, reveals relevant information about the flea species
   richness on opossums in fragmented habitats in a suburban landscape in
   Queretaro. Because fleas have potential as disease and parasite vectors,
   this new information may be helpful in assessing their effects on human
   and wildlife health.
C1 Hernandez-Camacho, Norma; Univ Autonoma Queretaro, Cuerpo Acad Ecol &
   Diversidad Faunist, Santiago De Queretaro, Queretaro, 76230, Mexico,
   Mexico.
EM norma.hernandez@uaq.mx
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 2007-3364
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts;
   Habitat; Man made habitat; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America
DE Ctenocephalides felis; Euhoplopsyllus glacialis affinnis; Polygenis
   martinezbaezi; Polygenis sp. [Mammalian hosts / Didelphis virginiana /
   New record] [Urban habitat / Suburban landscape / ] [Mexico /  / ]. 
   Didelphis virginiana [Siphonapteran parasites / Ctenocephalides felis /
   New record] [ / Euhoplopsyllus glacialis affinnis / ] [ / Polygenis
   martinezbaezi / ] [ / Polygenis sp. / ] [Urban habitat / Suburban
   landscape / ] [Mexico /  / ].

DT Article
TI Description of a new species of the genus Scaphella (Gastropoda:
   Volutidae) of Danian limestones (Lower Paleocene) from the Paris Basin.
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
   Meyer, Jean-Claude
SO Xenophora
SU 3
PS 8-14
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
NT French version abridged.
LA English; French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The systematic study of fossil impressions of mollusks obtained via
   silicone rubber casts, reveals unexpected faunal diversity. A large new
   species of the genus Scaphella was thus recognized in the Danian (Early
   Paleocene) limestones of Vigny (Val d'Oise, France) based on several
   well preserved external impressions. It is the third species of this
   genus identified in the Paleocene of the Paris Basin; it is also the
   fourth species of this genus described from the Danian.

DT Article
TI Recent findings from the Islands of Maio and Boa Vista in the Cape Verde
   Archipelago, West Africa: Description of three new Africonus species
   (Gastropoda: Conidae).
AU Afonso, Carlos M.L. (cmlafonso@ualg.pt) 
   Tenorio, Manuel J.
SO Xenophora
SU 3
PS 47-60
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
NT French version abridged.
LA English; French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species endemic to the Cape Verde Archipelago are described:
   Africonus santanaensis sp. nov. and Africonus gonsaloi sp. nov. from
   Maio Island, and Africonus condei sp. nov. from Boa Vista Island. A.
   santanaensis sp. nov. inhabits the northwest coast of Maio Island, and
   is compared with the taxa A. longilineus, A. grahami, A. infinitus and
   A. cf. claudiae. A. gonsaloi sp. nov. lives on the east coast of Maio
   Island, and is compared with A. raulsilvai, A. infinitus, A. damottai
   galeao and A. roeckeli. The new species A. condei sp. nov. has been
   found in the north coast of Boa Vista Island in Derrubado. It is
   compared with A. evorai and A. crotchii. Details on radula, living
   animal and morphometric analysis of the shells are provided.

AN ZOOR15009045080
DT Article
TI Systematics of Pseudotothyris (Loricariidae: Hypoptopomatinae).
AU Martins, Fernanda O. (fernanda_martins2@hotmail.com) 
   Britski, Heraldo A.
   Langeani, Francisco
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 170
IS 4
PS 822-874
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pseudotothyris Britski & Garavello, 1984 is a genus of small catfishes
   distributed only in coastal basins in southern and south-eastern Brazil,
   between Rio de Janeiro and Santa Catarina states. Schaefer (1991), in a
   phylogenetic analysis of the Hypoptopomatinae, did not find any uniquely
   derived character to diagnose Pseudotothyris, and thus questioned its
   taxonomic validity, suggesting that a more detailed comparative analysis
   would be necessary to find exclusive diagnostic characters of the genus.
   Based on this, the present study aimed to perform a phylogenetic
   analysis and taxonomic revision of the genus, evaluating its specific
   composition, its monophyly, and its phylogenetic relationships. For
   this, we performed a phylogenetic analysis with 92 characters observed
   across 57 terminal taxa, including members of the Delturinae,
   Loricariinae, Hypostominae, Neoplecostominae, and all valid genera of
   Hypoptopomatinae. Our results corroborate the monophyly of the genus,
   which is supported by a uniquely derived synapomorphy: anterior snout
   odontodes well developed only on dorsal region. As expected and already
   suggested by other authors, Pseudotothyris is recovered as the sister
   group of Otothyris, another genus that occurs in coastal drainages.
   Additionally, as a result of the taxonomic revision, we present a
   redescription of the genus and of the two valid species, and the
   description of a new species. [copyright] 2014 The Linnean Society of
   London
C1 Martins, Fernanda O.; Univ Estadual Paulista, UNESP, Rua Cristovao
   Colombo 2265, Sao Jose Do Rio Preto, SP, BR-15054000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fernanda_martins2@hotmail.com
RI Martins, Fernanda O/J-9396-2014; Langeani, Francisco/B-7880-2012
OI Langeani, Francisco/0000-0001-7376-4798
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0024-4082

   Pseudotothyris ignota [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates

   Siluriformes, Loricariidae
OR Hypoptopomatinae (Loricariidae): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 861]. 
   Pseudotothyris - Britski & Garavello 1984 (Loricariidae): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 824; Key to species, P. 825]. 
   Pseudotothyris ignota (Loricariidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 825].

PT J
AN ZOOR15107043280
DT Article
TI Taxonomic review of the subfamily Schoenobiinae (Lepidoptera:
   Pyraloidea: Crambidae) from China.
AU Chen, Fu-Qiang
   Wu, Chun-Sheng (chenfq@ioz.ac.cn) 
SO Zoological Systematics
VL 39
IS 2
PS 163-208
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The taxonomy of the Chinese Schoenobiinae is revised. In total, 12
   genera and 49 species are recognized. This paper presents keys to the
   genera and species, illustrations of wing venation for each genus, and
   line drawings of genitalia of most species. Two new species, namely,
   Schoenobius scirpus sp.nov. and Ramila minima sp.nov., are described.
   The female of Scirpophaga adunctella Chen, Song, and Wu, 2006 is
   reported for the first time. Donacaula forficellus (Thunberg, 1794)
   reported by Wang (1980) is proven to be a misidentification of S.
   scirpus sp.nov. The diagnostic characteristics of Schoenobiinae and the
   taxonomic status of some genera are discussed. Acropentias, Leechia,
   Brihaspa, and Promacrochilo are suggested to be removed from the
   subfamily because these genera do not share any synapomorphic characters
   with Schoenobiinae.
C1 Wu, Chun-Sheng; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Beijing, 100101, China,
   China.
EM chenfq@ioz.ac.cn

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Macrobiotus (Tardigrada: Macrobiotidae) from
   Southeastern China.
AU Zhang, Pin
   Sun, Xi-Zhai (sxzhzu@126.com) 
SO Zoological Systematics
VL 39
IS 2
PS 224-228
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species Macrobiotus wuyishanensis sp. nov. (Tardigrada:
   Macrobiotidae) is described from Mt. Wuyi, Southeastern China. It is
   most similar to Macrobiotus spectabilis Thulin, 1928, but differs by
   lacking fine punctuation on the distal half of the projections on the
   egg, a ring of polygons that circle the base of each projection, and
   punctation between the projections on the egg shell. It is also similar
   to M grandis Richters, 1911, but differs by smaller body size, lacking
   polygons and punctations between the projections on egg shell.
C1 Sun, Xi-Zhai; Shaanxi Normal Univ, Coll Life Sci, Xian, 710062, China,
   China.

AB A new species of Aequales group, namely Gieysztoria shiyanensis Wang &
   Xia, sp. nov., is described from China. The new species is diagnosed by
   a sclerotic stylet with a belt attaching 15 fang-like spines. A

   China are provided.

DT Article
TI Four new feather mite species of the genus Proctophyllodes Robin
   (Astigmata: Proctophyllodidae) from China.
AU Wang, Zi-Ying

TI A new species of the genus Neoribates (Neoribates) (Acari: Oribatida:
   Parakalummidae) from China.
AU Liang, Wen-Qin
   Yang, Mao-Fa (yangmaofa@sohu.com) 
   Tang, Qiu-Xiao
SO Zoological Systematics
VL 39
IS 2
PS 259-262
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Neoribates (Neon bates) cupulatus sp. nov. is described
   from Yunnan, China. It can be easily distinguished from other known
   congeners by the following combination of morphological characters: body
   size small; sensilli cupped, with a short stalk and rounded clavated
   head, bothridium lamellate; adanal setae ad3 inserted laterally to the
   anal plates, positioned from iad at a large distance, and in a line with
   an2.

TI A new species and a new record of the genus Balanococcus Williams
   (Hemiptera: Coccoidea: Pseudococcidae) from China.
AU Li, Wen-Chao
   Wu, San-An (sananwu@bjfu.edu.cn) 
SO Zoological Systematics
VL 39
IS 2
PS 269-274
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species and a new record of the genus Balanococcus Williams are
   described from China. They are B. zhejiangensis sp. nov. and B. kwoni
   Pellizzari & Danzig, 2007. The new species, collected from Zhejiang,
   China under leaf sheath of Phyllostachys praecox, is similar to B. kwoni
   Pellizzari & Danzig, but can be distinguished by its hind coxa inflated,
   and only small type of oral collar tubular ducts present on dorsal
   surface. A key to Chinese species of Balanococcus is given. All
   specimens examined are deposited in the Insect Collection of Beijing
   Forestry University.

TI Three new species of sanguinolenta-group of the genus Macrophya
   (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae) from China.
AU Li, Ze-Jian
   Lei, Zhen
   Wang, Jun-Feng
   Wei, Mei-Cai (lizejian2006@163.com) 
SO Zoological Systematics
VL 39
IS 2
PS 297-308
PD Apr 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Macrophya opacifrontalis Li, Lei & Wei, sp. nov., M pseudofemorata Li,
   Wang, & Wei, sp. nov., and M huangi Li & Wei, sp. nov. of the
   sanguinolenta-group of Macrophya (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae) from
   China are described. M opacifrontalis and M pseudofemorata is belong to
   the tongi-subgroup, whereas M huangi belongs to the depressinasubgroup.
   The division of the tongi and depressina subgroups and species inside
   are briefly discussed. Keys to all known species of the tongi and
   depressina-subgroups from China are provided respectively.

TI New species of Vaejovis from the Santa Rita Mountains, southern Arizona
   (Scorpiones: Vaejovidae).
AU Ayrey, Richard F.
   Soleglad, Michael E.
SO Euscorpius
VL 183
PS 1-13
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new scorpion species, Vaejovis grahami sp. nov. is described. This
   small, dark brown species is found in the Santa Rita Mountains, Santa
   Cruz County, Arizona, USA. It is most similar to V. vorhiesi Stahnke and
   V. deboerae Ayrey. The pedipalp fixed finger usually has 5 inner
   denticles (ID) and the movable finger has 6, like in most other southern
   Arizona Vaejovis.

PM 24631245
DT Article
TI Unique Feeding Morphology in a New Prognathous Extinct Porpoise from the
   Pliocene of California.
AU Racicot, Rachel A. (rachel.racicot@yale.edu) 
   Demere, Thomas A.
   Beatty, Brian L.
   Boessenecker, Robert W.
SO Current Biology
VL 24
IS 7
PS 774-779
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Modern porpoises (Odontoceti: Phocoenidae) are some of the smallest
   cetaceans and usually feed near the seafloor on small fish and
   cephalopods (1-3). Within both extinct and extant phocoenids, no
   evidence for specialized mandibular morphology has been documented
   (4-7). Here we describe a new species of extinct porpoise, Semirostrum
   ceruttii, from the marine Pliocene San Diego (4.2-1.6 megaannum, Ma) and
   Purisima (5-2.5 Ma) formations of California. The mandibles comprise a
   long, fused, and nearly edentulous prognathous symphysis, extending
   farther beyond the rostrum than in any known mammal. Phylogenetic
   analyses based on morphology reconstruct Semirostrum ceruttii as sister
   to extant (crown) porpoise species with moderate support. We describe
   the spectacularly preserved holotype specimen based on computed
   tomography (CT) scans, which allowed visualization of the elongate
   mental and accessory canals within the symphysis. The elongate canals
   are similar to those found in Rynchops birds (8) and were likely
   involved in sensory function. Oblique labial wear facets present on
   numerous small conical mandibular teeth posterior to the symphysis
   suggest regular contact with benthic substrate. The unique mandibular
   and dental characteristics, along with robust scapulae, sternum, and
   unfused cervical vertebrae, support the interpretation that this species
   employed a form of benthic skim feeding by using its mandible to probe
   for and obtain prey.
C1 Racicot, Rachel A.; Yale Univ, Dept Geol & Geophys, 210 Whitney Ave, New
   Haven, CT, 06511, USA, USA.
EM rachel.racicot@yale.edu
OI Demere, Thomas/0000-0001-5464-3528
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0960-9822
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Semirostrum [Pliocene /  / New genus]. 
   Semirostrum ceruttii [California /  / new species] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Cetacea, Phocoenidae
OR Semirostrum (Phocoenidae): [Gen nov, Type species Semirostrum ceruttii,
   p. 774, Pliocene; Fossil]. 
   Semirostrum ceruttii (Phocoenidae): [Sp nov, California, Pliocene, P.
   774; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011059862
OA Bronze

AN ZOOR15011059863
PM 24631241
DT Article
TI Exceptionally Preserved 450-Million-Year-Old Ordovician Ostracods with
   Brood Care.
AU Siveter, David J. (djs@leicester.ac.uk) 
   Tanaka, Gengo
   Farrell, Una C.
   Martin, Markus J.
   Siveter, Derek J.
   Briggs, Derek E.G.
SO Current Biology
VL 24
IS 7
PS 801-806
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 27
AB Ostracod crustaceans are the most abundant fossil arthropods and are
   characterized by a long stratigraphic range. However, their soft parts
   are very rarely preserved, and the presence of ostracods in rocks older
   than the Silurian period (1-5) was hitherto based on the occurrence of
   their supposed shells. Pyritized ostracods that preserve limbs and in
   situ embryos, including an egg within an ovary and possible hatched
   individuals, are here described from rocks of the Upper Ordovician
   Katian Stage Lorraine Group of New York State, including examples from
   the famous Beecher's Trilobite Bed (6, 7). This discovery extends our
   knowledge of the paleobiology of ostracods by some 25 million years and
   provides the first unequivocal demonstration of ostracods in the
   Ordovician period, including the oldest known myodocope, Luprisca incuba
   gen. et sp. nov. It also provides conclusive evidence of a developmental
   brood-care strategy conserved within Ostracoda for at least 450 million
   years.
C1 Siveter, David J.; Univ Leicester, Dept Geol, Leicester, Leics, LE1 7RH,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM djs@leicester.ac.uk
SC Paleontology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0960-9822
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Reproduction; Reproductive
   behaviour; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA;
   Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Luprisca [Ordovician /  / New genus]. 
   Luprisca incuba [New York /  / new species] [Ordovician /  / ]. 
   Myodocopa [Parental care / Brooding / oldest record] [Evolution /
   Evolutionary conserved strategy / ] [New York /  / stratigraphical
   distribution] [Ordovician / Katian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Luprisca (Ostracoda): [Gen nov, Of Myodocopida?, Type species Luprisca
   incuba, p. 801, Ordovician; Fossil]. 
   Luprisca incuba (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, New York, Ordovician, P. 801;
   Fossil]. 
   Myodocopa (Ostracoda): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011059863
OA Bronze
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15011059864
PM 24656829
DT Article
TI Mikrocytids Are a Broadly Distributed and Divergent Radiation of
   Parasites in Aquatic Invertebrates.
AU Hartikainen, Hanna
   Stentiford, Grant D. (grant.stentiford@cefas.co.uk) 
   Bateman, Kelly S.
   Berney, Cedric
   Feist, Stephen W.
   Longshaw, Matt
   Okamura, Beth
   Stone, David
   Ward, Georgia
   Wood, Charlotte
   Bass, David
SO Current Biology
VL 24
IS 7
PS 807-812
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
NT Supplemental information available online
   http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2014.02.033
LA English
U1 1
U2 42
AB Microcell parasites have independently evolved in several eukaryotic
   lineages and are increasingly recognized as important and emerging
   pathogens of diverse hosts, including species of economic importance
   subject to international legislation concerning the trading of aquatic
   animals (1-3). The microcell Mikrocytos mackini causes Denman Island
   disease of oysters and represents one of the most genetically divergent
   eukaryotes known. Mikrocytos has remained an isolated lineage with a
   limited distribution. We investigated two emerging diseases of juvenile
   crabs and oysters from the UK using massively parallel sequencing and
   targeted primer approaches to reveal that their causative agents are
   highly divergent lineages related to M. mackini (Paramikrocytos canceri
   n. gen. et n. sp. and M. mimicus sp. nov., respectively). We demonstrate
   a major new globally distributed parasite radiation (Mikrocytida ord.
   nov.) with phylogenetic affinities to the commercially important
   haplosporidian parasites of invertebrates. Mikrocytids have eluded
   detection because of their small size, intracellular habit, and extreme
   sequence divergence. P. canceri was frequently detected in a range of
   shoreline invertebrates, demonstrating that these newly recognized
   parasites are in fact common, diverse, and widespread and should be
   considered when assessing the risks of aquaculture activities, invasive
   species spread, and movements of ballast water and sediments with
   associated invertebrates.
C1 Stentiford, Grant D.; Cefas, Barrack Rd, Weymouth, Dorset, DT4 8UB,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM grant.stentiford@cefas.co.uk

   Kelly/0000-0002-9124-2333; Berney, Cedric/0000-0001-8689-9907

SN 0960-9822

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic

   parasite species] [North Atlantic / United Kingdom, England / New
   protozoan parasite species]. 
   Crassostrea gigas [Protozoan parasites / Mikrocytos mimicus / New
   parasite species] [North Sea / United Kingdom, England / New protozoan
   parasite species]. 
   Mikrocytos mimicus [Molluscan hosts / Crassostrea gigas / New parasite

   molluscan host].

   Ostreoida, Ostreoidea, Protozoa

   Crassostrea gigas (Ostreoidea): [Host].

   (new), p. 808].

   Mikrocytos Farley et al. 1988, p. 808]. 
   Mikrocytos - Farley et al. 1988 (Protozoa): [Designated type genus for
   new family, Mikrocytiidae, p. 808]. 
   Mikrocytos mimicus (Protozoa): [Sp nov, United Kingdom, England
   (marine), Parasite of Crassostrea gigas (Mollusca), p. 808; Parasite]. 
   Paramikrocytos (Protozoa): [Gen nov, Of new family Mikrocytiidae, Type
   species Paramikrocytos canceri, p. 808]. 
   Paramikrocytos canceri (Protozoa): [Sp nov, United Kingdom, England
   (marine), Parasite of Cancer pagurus (Crustacea), p. 808; Parasite].

PT J

PM 24872060
DT Article
TI A revision of the lysianassid genus Waldeckia with the description of
   four new species (Crustacea, Amphipoda, Lysianassidae, Waldeckiinae
   subfam. nov.).
AU Lowry, J.K. (jim.lowry@austmus.gov.au) 
   Kilgallen, N.M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 4
PS 301-345
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Waldeckia Chevreux is a genus of scavenging lysianassoid amphipods with
   distribution records from Antarctica, Australia, Thailand, Indonesia,
   Singapore, the Philippines, Vietnam, China and Japan. The genus is
   revised and diagnosed against all other genera of the Lysianassidae and
   the subfamily Waldeckiinae is established. All known species are
   redescribed and a key is provided. Three new species of Waldeckia (W.
   dempseyae sp. nov., W. tangaroa sp. nov., W. warreen sp. nov.) are
   described from Australian waters, and one (W. selayarensis sp. nov.)
   from Indonesia and Australia. Waldeckia crenulata Pirlot, 1936, from the
   Philippines and Indonesia, is described in detail for the first time.
   Waldeckia chevreuxi Stebbing, 1910 is placed in the synonymy of W.
   nitens, and W. elephas is placed in the synonymy of W. nudum. Orchomene
   orchospina Hirayama, 1986 and O. tomiokaensis Hirayama, 1986 are
   transferred to Waldeckia. Waldeckia scrupulosa Mateus & Mateus, 1986
   cannot be placed in a genus based on the original description. This
   revision brings the number of species in the genus to 14.
C1 Lowry, J.K.; Australian Museum, Marine Invertebrates Sect, 6 Coll St,
   Sydney, NSW, 2010, Australia, Australia.
EM jim.lowry@austmus.gov.au
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Type material;
   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key;
   Marine zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Waldeckia dempseyae [South Indian Ocean / Australia, South Australia /
   New species] [South Pacific / Australia, New South Wales / ] [ /
   Australia, Tasmania / ]. 
   Waldeckia selayarensis [South Pacific / Australia, Western Australia /
   New species] [ / Indonesia / ]. 
   Waldeckia tangaroa [South Pacific / Australia, New South Wales / New
   species] [ / Australia, Victoria / ]. 
   Waldeckia warreen [South Pacific / Australia, Tasmania / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda

   Waldeckia, p. 333]. 
   Orchomene tomiokaensis - Hirayama 1986 (Amphipoda): [Referred to,
   Waldeckia, p. 339]. 
   Waldeckia - Chevreux 1906 (Amphipoda): [Revision, P. 304; Designated
   type genus for new subfamily, Waldeckiinae, p. 303; Key to species, P.

   Waldeckia australiensis - (Haswell 1879) (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P.
   311]. 
   Waldeckia brachycephala - Ren 1998 (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P. 312].

   312; Redescription, P. 313]. 
   Waldeckia dempseyae (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Australia, New South Wales
   (marine), P. 314].

   synonym, Of Waldeckia nudum (Imbach 1967), p. 332]. 
   Waldeckia enoei - Stephensen 1931 (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P. 323].

   Waldeckia nitens - (Haswell 1879) (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P. 328;
   Syn nov, Waldeckia chevreuxi Stebbing 1910, p. 327]. 
   Waldeckia nudum - (Imbach 1967) (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P. 332;
   Senior synonym, Of Waldeckia elephas Hirayama & Kikuchi 1980, p. 332]. 
   Waldeckia obesa - (Chevreux 1905) (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P. 332]. 
   Waldeckia orchospina - (Hirayama 1986) (Amphipoda): [Redescription, P.
   333; Comb nov, Transferred from Orchomene, p. 333]. 
   Waldeckia scrupulosa - Mateus & Mateus 1986 (Amphipoda): [Status, P.

   Waldeckia selayarensis (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Indonesia (marine), P.
   333].

PT J
AN ZOOR15010051121
DT Article
TI Aracia sinaloae sp n., a new brooding, simultaneous hermaphroditic fan
   worm from southern Gulf of California (Polychaeta: Sabellidae).
AU Ana Tovar-Hernandez, Maria (maria_ana_tovar@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 4
PS 389-400
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Currently, only two species are known in the sabellid genus Aracia: A.
   riwo (Rouse, 1996) and A. heterobranchiata (Nogueira, Lopez & Rossi,
   2004). The first was described from the surface of a Teredo-riddled log
   lying in 1 m of water among mangrove roots, in Papua (New Guinea),
   whilst the second was found on an organically enriched beach at Sao
   Sebastiao (Brazil). In this contribution, a third species of Aracia is
   described from settling panels and red mangrove roots in an estuarine
   system located in southern Gulf of California (Mexico). The new species
   is a simultaneous hermaphrodite and brooder, unique in the presence of a
   rectangular ventral shield on the collar, shorter than those in
   posterior thoracic segments; and a high number of rows of teeth in
   thoracic and abdominal uncini, covering from one-half to three-quarters
   of the main fang length. Information about color patterns in live
   specimens, glandular patterns, and reproduction is provided.
C1 Ana Tovar-Hernandez, Maria; El Colegio Sinaloa AC, Gral Antonio Rosales
   435 Poniente, Culiacan, Sinaloa, 80000, Mexico, Mexico.
EM maria_ana_tovar@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Aracia sinaloae [North Pacific / Mexico / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Aracia - Nogueira, Fitzhugh & Rossi 2010 (Polychaeta): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 397]. 
   Aracia sinaloae (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 390].

PT J
AN ZOOR15010051122
PM 24872063
DT Article
TI A revision of the late Eocene snakeflies (Raphidioptera) of the
   Florissant Formation, Colorado, with special reference to the wing
   venation of the Raphidiomorpha.
AU Makarkin, Vladimir N.
   Archibald, S. Bruce (vnmakarkin@mail.ru) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 4
PS 401-444
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The snakeflies (Raphidioptera) of the late Eocene Florissant Formation
   (Colorado, USA) are revised. Seven species of Raphidiidae are assigned
   to three genera, i.e., Megaraphidia Cockerell, 1907, Archiraphidia
   Handlirsch, 1910, and Florissantoraphidia gen. nov. Dictyoraphidia
   Handlirsch, 1910 is assigned to Baissopteridae, a first Cenozoic record
   of the family. Archiraphidia tumulata (Scudder, 1890), A. tranquilla
   (Scudder, 1890) and A.? somnolenta (Scudder, 1890), stat. res. are
   treated as distinct species, and A. eventa (Scudder, 1890) as a new
   synonym of A. tranquilla. The lectotype of A. eventa is designated.
   'Raphidia' exhumata Cockerell, 1909 is transferred to Megaraphidia.
   'Raphidia' mortua Rohwer, 1909 and 'R.' funerata Engel, 2003 constitute
   Florissantoraphidia gen. nov. Our findings support the treatment of the
   single Florissant species of Inocelliidae as preliminary assigned to
   Fibla Navas, 1915. We examine venational synapomorphies of
   Raphidiomorpha and provide a new diagnosis for it based on these
   characters. We evaluate putative derived venational character states of
   'Neoraphidioptera' (Inocelliidae and Raphidiidae), finding no clear
   synapomorphy supporting its validity; these families may nest separately
   within a paraphyletic Mesoraphidiidae (s.l.). We provide diagnoses for
   the families occurring at Florissant (Baissopteridae, Inocelliidae and
   Raphidiidae) based on wing venation.
C1 Archibald, S. Bruce; Simon Fraser Univ, Dept Biol Sci, 8888 Univ Dr,
   Burnaby, BC, V5A 1S6, Canada, Canada.
EM vnmakarkin@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Baissopteridae [Caenozoic /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Florissantoraphidia [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Raphidioptera [Colorado /  / systematics] [Eocene / Late Eocene / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Raphidioptera
OR Raphidioptera (Insecta): [Revision, P. 405; Fossil]. 
   Archiraphidia tranquilla - (Scudder 1890) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 424; Syn nov, Archiraphidia? eventa (Scudder 1890),
   p. 424; Removal from synonymy, Archiraphidia? somnolenta (Scudder 1890),
   p. 429]. 
   Archiraphidia tumulata - (Scudder 1890) (Raphidioptera): [Redescription,
   P. 421]. 
   Archiraphidia? somnolenta - (Scudder 1890) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 429; Removal from synonymy, With Archiraphidia
   tranquilla (Scudder 1890), p. 429]. 
   Baissopteridae - Martynova 1961 (Raphidioptera): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   409; Fossil]. 
   Dictyoraphidia - Handlirsch 1910 (Raphidioptera): [Referred to,
   Baissopteridae, p. 402]. 
   Dictyoraphidia veterana - (Scudder 1890) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 411]. 
   Florissantoraphidia (Raphidioptera): [Gen nov, Of family Raphidiidae,
   Type species Raphidia funerata Engel 2003, p. 432, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Florissantoraphidia funerata - (Engel 2003) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 434; Comb nov, Transferred from Raphidia, p. 434]. 
   Florissantoraphidia mortua - (Rohwer 1909) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 432; Comb nov, Transferred from Raphidia, p. 432]. 
   Inocellia eventa - Scudder 1890 (Raphidioptera): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 429]. 
   Inocelliidae - Navas 1913 (Raphidioptera): [Emended diagnosis, P. 436]. 
   Megaraphidia elegans - Cockerell 1907 (Raphidioptera): [Redescription,
   P. 414]. 
   Megaraphidia exhumata - (Cockerell 1909) (Raphidioptera):
   [Redescription, P. 417; Comb nov, Transferred from Raphidia, p. 416]. 
   Raphidia exhumata - Cockerell 1909 (Raphidioptera): [Referred to,
   Megaraphidia, p. 416]. 
   Raphidia funerata - Engel 2003 (Raphidioptera): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Florissantoraphidia, p. 432]. 
   Raphidia mortua - Rohwer 1909 (Raphidioptera): [Referred to, New genus
   Florissantoraphidia, p. 432]. 
   Raphidiidae - Latreille 1810 (Raphidioptera): [Emended diagnosis, P.

DT Article
TI A study on the genus Compsidolon Reuter, 1899 from China (Hemiptera:
   Heteroptera: Miridae: Phylinae), with descriptions of three new species.
AU Li, Xiao-Ming
   Liu, Guo-Qing (liugq@nankai.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 4
PS 469-483
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Compsidolon Reuter from China with eleven species is reviewed here.
   Three of them, C. ailaoshanensis, C. flavidum, and C. pilosum are
   described as new to science. C. eximium (Reuter) is recorded from China
   for the first time. Compsidolon punctulatum Qi and Nonnaizab, 1995 is
   treated as a junior synonym of Compsidolon nebulosum ( Reuter, 1878). A
   key to Chinese species of Compsidolon Reuter is given. Photographs of
   dorsal habitus, scanning electron micrographs of metathoracic
   scent-gland, and illustrations of male genitalia are also provided. All
   type specimens are deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Nankai
   University, Tianjin, China.
C1 Liu, Guo-Qing; Nankai Univ, Inst Entomol, Tianjin, 300071, China, China.
EM liugq@nankai.edu.cn

TI A new species and first record of the genus Shoemakerella Pirlot, 1936
   (Crustacea: Amphipoda: Lysianassidae) from Brazil.
AU Sorrentino, Rayane (raysrcanp@gmail.com) 
   Senna, Andre R.
   Lowry, James K.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 4
PS 484-492
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the genus Shoemakerella Pirlot, 1936 is described for
   the Southeastern Brazilian continental shelf. The new species is easily
   recognized from the others in the genus mainly by the shape of the
   gnathopod 2. This is the first species of Shoemakerella from Brazilian
   waters.

DT Article
TI Japanese Species of the Myrmecophilous Genus Thiasophila Kraatz, 1856
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Aleocharinae).
AU Maruyama, Munetoshi (dendrolasius@gmail.com) 
   Zerche, Lothar
SO Esakia
VL 54
PS 17-25
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Faunistic investigation of Japanese myrmecophiles revealed the
   occurrence of three new species of the genus Thiasophila Kraatz, 1856,
   which are described herein: T nipponica sp. nov. (host: Lasius
   (Dendrolasius) sp.; from Hokkaido and Honshu), T aynumosir sp. nov.
   (host: Formica truncorum; from Hokkaido), T shinanonis sp. nov. (host: E
   yessensis; from Honshu). The two species of Thiasophila recorded from
   Japan prior to this work appear not to belong to this genus. A key to
   the Japanese species is provided.
C1 Maruyama, Munetoshi; Kyushu Univ Museum, Fukuoka, 8128581, Japan, Japan.
EM dendrolasius@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0071-1268
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Associations; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Formica truncorum [Associations / Thiasophila aynumosir (Coleoptera) /
   New associate species] [Japan /  / New associated coleopteran species]. 
   Formica yessensis [Associations / Thiasophila shinanonis (Coleoptera) /
   New associate species] [Japan /  / New associated coleopteran species]. 
   Lasius (Dendrolasius) [Associations / Thiasophila nipponica (Coleoptera)
   / New associate species] [Japan /  / New associated coleopteran
   species]. 
   Thiasophila [Japan /  / Key to species]. 
   Thiasophila aynumosir [Associations / Formica truncorum (Hymenoptera) /
   New associate species] [Japan /  / New species; hymenopteran associate].
   
   Thiasophila nipponica [Associations / Lasius (Dendrolasius)
   (Hymenoptera) / New associate species] [Japan /  / New species;
   hymenopteran associate]. 
   Thiasophila shinanonis [Associations / Formica yessensis (Hymenoptera) /
   New associate species] [Japan /  / New species; hymenopteran associate].
   
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Formicoidea, Formicidae

DT Article
TI Four New Species of Ceratoderus Westwood, 1842 (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Paussinae) from Indochina.
AU Maruyama, Munetoshi (dendrolasius@gmail.com) 
SO Esakia
VL 54
PS 33-40
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Ceratoderus Westwood, 1842 are described from
   Indochina: C. jendeki sp. nov. (Central Laos), C. kentaroi sp. nov.
   (Southern Vietnam), C. yunnanensis sp. nov. (Yunnan, China), and C.
   akikoae sp. nov. (Northern Vietnam). They are similar to C. bifasciatus
   (Kollar, 1836), C. tonkinensis Wasmann, 1921 or C. venustus Hisamatsu,
   1963, which are redescribed to distinguish from the new species.
C1 Maruyama, Munetoshi; Kyushu Univ Museum, Fukuoka, 8128581, Japan, Japan.
EM dendrolasius@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0071-1268

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   Ceratoderus jendeki [Laos /  / New species]. 
   Ceratoderus tonkinensis [Laos /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Ceratoderus yunnanensis [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Ceratoderus akikoae (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 39]. 
   Ceratoderus bifasciatus - (Kollar 1836) (Carabidae): [Redescription, P.
   34].

   Ceratoderus kentaroi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 36]. 
   Ceratoderus tonkinensis - Wasmann 1921 (Carabidae): [New record]. 
   Ceratoderus venustus - Hisamatsu 1963 (Carabidae): [Redescription, P.

DT Article
TI Five New Species of the Intertidal Genus Halorhadinus Sawada, 1971
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Aleocharinae) from Japan.
AU Ono, Hiroki (dendrolasius@gmail.com) 
   Maruyama, Munetoshi
SO Esakia
VL 54
PS 41-50
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species of the intertidal aleocharine genus Halorhadinus are
   described: Halorhadinus kawashimai sp. nov. (from Honshu), H. miyataorum
   sp. nov. (from Shikoku), H. miyakei sp. nov. (from Kyushu), H. masakazui
   sp. nov. (from Honshu and Kyushu), H. satoi sp. nov. (from Honshu,
   shikoku and Kyushu). The following new locality records are given:
   Halorhadinus aequalis Sawada, 1971 (from Izushoto, Shikoku and Kyushu)
   and H. sawadai Maruyama & Hayashi, 2009 (from Shikoku). A key to the
   species of the genus and biological notes are provided.

   Japan.

   Halorhadinus miyataorum; Halorhadinus satoi [Japan /  / New species]. 
   Halorhadinus sawadai [Japan / Shikoku / New record].

TI A Taxonomic Study of Aphelopus Dalman from Japan, with Descriptions of
   Two New Species (Hymenoptera: Dryinidae: Aphelopinae).
AU Mita, Toshiharu (tkp_ex@hotmail.com) 
   Olmi, Massimo
SO Esakia
VL 54
PS 91-101
PD Mar 31 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Aphelopus Daman from Japan was taxonomically revised.
   Aphelopus koreanus Olmi and A. camus were newly recorded, and A.
   nivealis, n. sp. and A. prolatus, n. sp. were described as new to
   science. A key to the species found in Japan was provided.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic Studies on the Genus Apophylia from Taiwan (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae: Galerucinae).
AU Lee, Chi-Feng (chifeng@tari.gov.tw) 
   Bezdek, Jan
SO Journal of Taiwan Agricultural Research
VL 63
IS 1
PS 1-16
PD Mar 30 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Taiwanese species of Apophylia Thomson are reviewed. Four species
   are redescribed: A. asahinai Chujo, 1962; A. beeneni Bezdek, 2003; A.
   miyamotoi Kimoto, 1969; and A. velai Bezdek, 2003. Two new synonyms are
   proposed: A. taiwanica Bezdek, 2003 as a junior synonym of A. asahinai
   Chajo, 1962; and A. kaoi Bezdek and Lee, 2009 as a junior synonym of A.
   velai Bezdek, 2003. Diagnostic characters of both sexes are illustrated.
   Occurrence of sibling species of cluysomelids in Taiwan is briefly
   discussed.
C1 Lee, Chi-Feng; Taiwan Agr Res Inst, Appl Zool Div, Taichung, Taiwan,
   Taiwan.
EM chifeng@tari.gov.tw
RI Bezdek, Jan/J-3548-2018
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Apophylia [Taiwan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Biology; distribution;
   systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae
OR Apophylia - Thomson 1858 (Chrysomelidae): [Key to species, Taiwan, P.
   13]. 
   Apophylia asahinai - Chujo 1962 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P. 4;
   Syn nov, Apophylia taiwanica Bezdek 2003, p. 3]. 
   Apophylia beeneni - Bezdek 2003 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P. 7]. 
   Apophylia miyamotoi - Kimoto 1969 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P.
   9]. 
   Apophylia velai - Bezdek 2003 (Chrysomelidae): [Redescription, P. 12;
   Syn nov, Apophylia kaoi Bezdek & Lee 2009, p. 11].

TI A new Neotropical species of the doryctine wasp tribe Holcobraconini
   (Hymenoptera: Braconidae), and new records of additional genera.
AU Braet, Yves (ybraet_kin@yahoo.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe Royale Belge d'Entomologie
VL 150
IS 1
PS 56-65
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The "Societe Entomologique Antilles-Guyane" (S.E.A.G.) has collected a
   specimen of Holcobraconini belonging to a new species of Nervellius
   Roman, 1924. The new taxon is described and included in a modified
   identification key of this genus. Additional distribution data about
   other Doryctinae species collected in French Guiana are given.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Sinstauchira from Yunnan Province
   (Orthoptera: Catantopidae).
AU Li, Xiaodong (lxdong_627@163.com) 
   Xu, Shengquan
   Zheng, Zhemin
SO Sichuan Journal of Zoology
VL 33
IS 2
PS 221-223
PD March 28 2014
PY 2014
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Sinstauchira (Orthoptera, Catantopidae) was
   described in this study. The type specimens are deposited in the
   Institute of Zoology, Shaanxi Normal Univeristy. Sinstauchira puerensis
   sp. nov. (Plate, 1~12). The new species is similar to Sinstauchira
   ruficornis Huang et Xia, 1984, but differs in: 1) Longitudinal diameter
   of eyes about 1.8 times longer than subocular furrow; 2) Tegmen reach to
   the seven tenths of hind femur; 3) Hind tarsus not beyond the half part
   of hind tibia. Body length: [male] 16.0~17.0 mm, [female] 21.0~23.0 mm;
   Pronotum length: [male] 3.0~3.5 mm, [female] 4.0~5.0 mm; Length of
   tegmen: [male] 9.5~10.0 mm, [female] 12.5~14.0 mm; Length of hind femur:
   [male] 9.5~11.0 mm,[female] 11.0~12.0 mm. Holotype [male], paratypes
   1[male], 5[female][female], Yunnan, Pu'er, Caiyanghe Nature Reserve
   (22[degree]30[minute]N, 101[degree]11[minute]E), 28 July in 2007,
   collected by Xu Shengquan. Etymology: The new species name is from the
   type locality Pu'er, China.
C1 Li, Xiaodong; Department of Chemistry and Life Science, Hechi
   University, Yizhou, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region 546300, China,
   China.
EM lxdong_627@163.com
SC Zoology
SN 1000-7083
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Sinstauchira puerensis [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria
OR Sinstauchira puerensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 221].

PT J
AN ZOOR15008039520

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Ophioteichus HL Clark, 1938 (Ophiuroidea:
   Ophiolepididae).
AU Pineda-Enriquez, Tania (tania_pinedae@hotmail.com) 
   Solis-Marin, Francisco A.
   Laguarda-Figueras, Alfredo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 3
PS 241-250
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In this study we re-describe the ophiuroid genus Ophioteichus H. L.
   Clark, 1938 and diagnose the species using existing and new characters
   found by examining the type material. The species Ophiolepis utinomii
   Irimura, 1967, is very similar to the holotype of Ophioteichus
   multispinum, and is herein transferred to the genus Ophioteichus; this
   transfer expands the geographic range of the genus. Ophioteichus is
   currently composed of three species: Ophioteichus parvispinum,
   Ophioteichus multispinum and Ophioteichus utinomii comb. nov. The genus
   is now known from the eastern part of Australia, Philippines and the
   coast of Japan, with a bathymetric range from littoral down to 45.3 m.
C1 Pineda-Enriquez, Tania; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, ICML, Mexico City,
   DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM tania_pinedae@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Ophioteichus [Pacific Ocean /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Ophioteichus multispinum [North Pacific / Philippines / New record]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Stelleroidea, Ophiuroidea
OR Ophiolepis utinomii - Irimura 1967 (Ophiuroidea): [Referred to,
   Ophioteichus, p. 245]. 
   Ophioteichus - Clark 1938 (Ophiuroidea): [Revision, P. 241; Emended
   diagnosis, P. 242; New record]. 
   Ophioteichus multispinum (Ophiuroidea): [New record]. 
   Ophioteichus utinomii - (Irimura 1967) (Ophiuroidea): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 245; Comb nov, Transferred from Ophiolepis, p. 245]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3784.3.3
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15008039520

AN ZOOR15008039521

AU Lowry, J.K. (jim.lowry@austmus.gov.au)

PS 251-258

U2 1
AB The new species Tongorchestia borabora sp. nov. is described from
   Vaitape in Bora Bora, Leeward Islands, Society Islands. This is the
   first talitrid amphipod reported from Bora Bora and the third species of
   Tongorchestia from the Western Pacific oceanic islands. Currently
   Tongorchestia is endemic to oceanic islands in the Western Pacific.

DT Article
TI A new species of Anacanthoroides and redescription of Apedunculata
   discoidea (Monogenoidea) parasitizing Prochilodus argenteus
   (Actinopterygii) from the Sao Francisco River, Brazil.
AU Monteiro, Cassandra Moraes (cassimonteiro@hotmail.com) 
   Brasil-Sato, Marilia Carvalho
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 3
PS 259-266
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Anacanthoroides sanctifrancisci n. sp. from the gills of
   'curimata-pacu', Prochilodus argenteus from the Sao Francisco River,
   Brazil, is described and illustrated. Anacanthoroides, monotypic, is
   represented by Anacanthoroides mizellei. The new species can be
   distinguished from A. mizellei by the presence of a pair of muscular
   pseudosuckers in the anterior region of the body, an accessory piece not
   articulated to the male copulatory organ and the number of rings in the
   male copulaty complex. Apedunculata discoidea is redescribed and
   recorded in the gills of P. argenteus. The generic diagnosis of
   Apedunculata is amended. Both genera are recorded for the first time in
   the Sao Francisco River basin.

DT Article
TI A new species of Duvalius from world's deepest cave (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae).
AU Reboleira, Ana Sofia P.S. (sreboleira@ua.pt) 
   Ortuno, Vicente M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 3
PS 267-274
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The new hypogean ground beetle, Duvalius abyssimus n. sp., from
   Krubera-Voronja, world's deepest cave (Arabika massif, Western Caucasus)
   is described and illustrated. Diagnostic morphological characters of the
   imago, male and female genitalia are provided. Its relations with other
   Duvalius Delarouzee species from the Western Caucasus geographic area
   are discussed. An updated overview of the biocoenosis of its peculiar
   habitat is made.

   Microweiseinae) from South Africa.
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
   Slipinski, Adam
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784

PS 275-280
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new genus of ladybird beetles, Ruthmuelleria, belonging to the
   pantropical tribe Carinodulini, is described based on a new species R.
   grootdrifensis from South Africa. The genus is diagnosed by the unique
   8-segmented antennae and posteriorly-directed metaventral postcoxal
   lines. A key to the genera and discussion of diagnostic characters of
   Carinodulini are also included.

PT J
AN ZOOR15104025927
DT Article
TI A new species of Casmaria H. Adams & A. Adams, 1853 (Gastropoda,
   Cassidae) from the Philippines identified by molecular data.
AU Fedosov, Alexander (fedosovalexander@gmail.com) 
   Olivera, Baldomero M.
   Watkins, Maren
   Barkalova, Varvara
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 78
PS 1-13
PD Mar 28 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The genus Casmaria H. Adams & A. Adams, 1853 (family Cassidae) is
   widespread in the tropical Indo-Pacific and has been documented from
   some Atlantic localities as well. Two Casmaria species, C. erinaceus
   (Linnaeus, 1758) and C. ponderosa (Gmelin, 1791), are common in
   Indo-Pacific shallow-water sandy bottom communities and are
   characterized by high morphological variability; both species encompass
   multiple, often sympatric forms of uncertain status. In the present
   study we carry out a phylogenetic analysis of some Philippine Casmaria
   morphs and demonstrate that one of the distinctive morphs earlier
   assigned to Casmaria ponderosa is in fact a different species, which we
   describe as Casmaria boblehmani sp. nov. The smooth form of Casmaria
   ponderosa, C. ponderosa ponderosa, and the solid nodulose form, widely
   called "form nodulosa" despite being strikingly different in shell
   morphology, are shown to be conspecific. Studied specimens of these two
   morphs even from different localities share the same haplotype of the
   CO1 gene. In light of these new data on the morphological variability of
   Casmaria species, we discuss criteria of species delimitation in the
   genus Casmaria and possible affinities of Casmaria boblehmani sp. nov.
   within the genus.
C1 Fedosov, Alexander; Russian Acad Sci, AN Severtsov Inst Ecol & Evolut,
   Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM fedosovalexander@gmail.com
RI Fedosov, Alexander/J-5400-2015
OI Fedosov, Alexander/0000-0002-8035-1403
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2118-9773
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Evolution; Variation;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Casmaria [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / systematics] [Morphological
   variation /  / ] [North Pacific / Philippines & Vietnam / ]. 
   Casmaria boblehmani [North Pacific / Philippines / New species] [South
   Pacific / Australia, Queensland / ] [ / Fiji / ] [ / Indonesia / ] [ /
   Society Islands / ] [ / Vanuatu / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda, Tonnoidea
OR Casmaria - H. Adams & A. Adams 1853 (Tonnoidea): [Diagnostic characters
   of subordinate taxa, P. 9]. 
   Casmaria boblehmani (Tonnoidea): [Sp nov, Philippines (marine), P. 6]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15104025927
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15009044925
PM 24872040
DT Article
TI New species of Hebefustis Siebenaller & Hessler 1977 (Isopoda, Asellota,
   Nannoniscidae) from the Clarion Clipperton Fracture Zone (equatorial NE
   Pacific).
AU Kaiser, Stefanie (Stefanie.Kaiser@senckenberg.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 101-119
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Macrofaunal collections obtained during the French-German BIONOD
   expedition to the Clarion Clipperton Fracture Zone (CCFZ), equatorial NE
   Pacific, in spring 2012 yielded two new nannoniscid species, Hebefustis
   juansenii sp. n. and H. vecino sp. n., which are described in the
   current paper. The number and position of posterolateral spines of the
   pleotelson distinguishes the two new species from all other species in
   the genus. Both species are similar to each other differ, though, in the
   length of maxilliped epipodite, the presence of a robust spine on
   pereonite 2 (in H. juansenii sp. n.) as well as the shape of pereonite 4
   anterior margin. They also resemble H. primitivus Menzies, 1962 but can
   be differentiated from the latter by the shape of lateral margins of
   pereonites 1-4 and the setation and shape of male pleopod 1. A
   distribution map and a taxonomic key to all known species in the genus
   are provided, as well as a checklist of known nannoniscid species from
   the Pacific is presented.
C1 Kaiser, Stefanie; German Ctr Marine Biodivers Res, DZMB, Sudstrand 44,
   Wilhelmshaven, D-26382, Germany, Germany.
EM Stefanie.Kaiser@senckenberg.de
OI Kaiser, Stefanie/0000-0003-2026-4663

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Publications; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   Hebefustis juansenii; Hebefustis vecino [North Pacific /  / New
   species]. 
   Nannoniscidae [Checklists /  / ] [Pacific Ocean /  / ].

   Modified key, p. 117].

DT Article
TI Endecous apterus: A new species of cave cricket from northeast Brazil,
   with comments on the use of subterranean habitats by Luzarinae crickets
   (Orthoptera: Grylloidea: Phalangopsidae: Luzarinae).
AU Souza-Dias, Pedro G.B. (pedrogdias@gmail.com) 
   Bolfarini, Marcio P.
   Nihei, Silvio S.
   De Mello, Francisco A.G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 120-130
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB In this study we describe the first apterous species of Endecous
   Saussure (1878), collected in two caves at Ituacu, Bahia State, Brazil.
   In Brazil, Endecous is the most widespread cricket in hypogean
   environments and its species can colonize caves and inhabit the entrance
   and the aphotic zones; Endecous species can also be found in the litter,
   rock gullies, crevices, burrows, and any natural cavities. The use of
   subterranean habitat by Endecous crickets and its related genera are
   discussed.
C1 Souza-Dias, Pedro G.B.; Univ Sao Paulo, Inst Biociencias, Rua
   Matao,Travessa 14,101,Cidade Univ, Sao Paulo, BR-05508900 BC, Brazil,

DT Article
TI Two new species of Neotyphloceras (Siphonaptera: Ctenophthalmidae) from
   Argentinean Patagonia.
AU Sanchez, Juliana (julianasanchez@cepave.edu.ar) 
   Lareschi, Marcela
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 159-170
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of Neotyphloceras Rothschild, parasites of sigmodontine
   rodents from Argentinean Patagonia, are described and illustrated: N.
   crackensis n. sp. and N. pardinasi n. sp. These species are compared
   with their morphologically closest relatives. Males are characterized by
   the shape of the upper lobe of the fixed process of clasper; the shape
   and chaetotaxy of the distal arm of sternum IX and by the shape of the
   crochet of the aedeagus; females by the contour of the distal margin of
   sternum VII. Neotyphloceras pardinasi n. sp. is reported from western
   Chubut Province, while N. crackensis n. sp. is known from the eastern
   regions of Chubut and Santa Cruz Provinces. With these reports, the
   geographical distribution of Neotyphloceras is extended to eastern
   Patagonia. A key to the species and subspecies of Neotyphloceras is
   provided.

   Argentina, Argentina.

PT J
AN ZOOR15009044930
PM 24872045
DT Article
TI A new species of the pontoniine shrimp genus Eupontonia (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Caridea: Palaemonidae) from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
AU Komai, Tomoyuki (komai@chiba-muse.or.jp) 
   Minemizu, Ryo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 171-178
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A third species of the pontoniine shrimp genus Eupontonia Bruce, 1971,
   E. gracilipes n. sp., is described and illustrated on the basis of a
   single female specimen collected from shallow water of Ishigaki Island,
   southern Ryukyu Islands, Japan. The new species is readily distinguished
   from the two congeneric species, E. noctalbata Bruce, 1971 and E. oahu
   Bruce, 2010, by a number of morphological characters, including the
   presence of a distinct postrostral median ridge and of the postrostral
   median tooth on the carapace. It is considered to be a free-living
   species. The generic diagnosis of Eupontonia is slightly emended to
   accommodate the present new species. A key in aid of identification of
   species of Eupontonia is provided.
C1 Komai, Tomoyuki; Nat Hist Museum & Inst, Chuo Ku, 955-2 Aoba Cho, Chiba,
   2608682, Japan, Japan.
EM komai@chiba-muse.or.jp
SC Zoology

PT J

PM 24872047
DT Article
TI A new Stygarctus (Arthrotardigrada: Stygarctidae) from Japan, with
   entangled seminal receptacle ducts.
AU Fujimoto, Shinta (shinta.f@water-bears.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 187-195
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Stygarctus ayatori sp. nov. (Arthrotardigrada: Stygarctidae), is
   described from a sandy beach located at Okinoshima, Tateyama Bay, Boso
   Peninsula, Honshu, Japan. The most prominent characters were observed in
   the female genital structure, with the seminal receptacle ducts forming
   a three-dimensional entanglement near the exterior opening, and internal
   thickening situated peripheral to the gonopore and between the gonopore
   and anus. The new species is distinguished from the congeners by these
   characters; excluding S. abornatus McKirdy et al., 1976 for which there
   is no information on the genital structure. However, S. ayatori sp. nov.
   and S. abornatus can be differentiated by the presence of dorsal spines
   on the former species, which are absent from the latter.
C1 Fujimoto, Shinta; Kyoto Univ, Dept Zool, Kitashirakawa Oiwakecho, Kyoto,
   6068502, Japan, Japan.
EM shinta.f@water-bears.com
OI Fujimoto, Shinta/0000-0002-1739-3010
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Stygarctus ayatori [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Tardigrada
OR Stygarctus ayatori (Tardigrada): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 188]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3784.2.8

PS 196-199
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Neobelocera medogensis sp. nov. (Hemiptera: Delphacidae: Delphacinae:
   Tropidocephalini) is described and illustrated from M? dog, Tibet,
   China. The new species can be easily separated from other known species
   in the genus Neobelocera by the color of tegmina and the form of the
   male genitalia. A key for separation of all known species of Neobelocera
   is also provided.

DT Article
TI Callibaetis Eaton (Ephemeroptera: Baetidae) from Brazil.
AU Cruz, Paulo Vilela (pvilelacruz@gmail.com) 
   Salles, Frederico Falcao
   Hamada, Neusa
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 48
IS 11-12
PS 591-660
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Callibaetis Eaton remains poorly known in South America. Some of the
   species in the genus are difficult to identify with confidence and most
   are known only at the adult stage. In this paper we increase the number
   of species known to occur in Brazil from 11 to 18; diagnoses of species
   are improved; five new species are described based on nymphs and reared
   adults of both genders (C.calloventer sp. nov., C.cruentus sp. nov.,
   C.gelidus sp. nov., C.itannae sp. nov., C.nigracyclus sp. nov.); first
   records of two species are reported from Brazil (C.gonzalezi and
   C.sellacki); descriptions of unknown stages are made (C.gonzalezi male
   imago and C.jocosus nymph); redescriptions of known stage are provided
   for male and female imago of C.jocosus. Based on these data, keys for
   nymph, male and female imago are proposed for
   Brazil.http://zoobank.org/urn: lsid: zoobank.org:
   pub:019D55A5-8979-4D9A-BB16-CB1451C8DF1B

PT J
AN ZOOR15008040322
DT Article
TI Prospection for predatory mites to control coconut pest mites in
   Thailand, with taxonomic descriptions of collected Mesostigmata (Acari).
AU da Silva, Renan V.
   Narita, Joao Paulo Z.
   Vichitbandha, Patchanee
   Chandrapatya, Angsumarn
   Konvipasruang, Ploychompoo
   Kongchuensin, Manita
   de Moraes, Gilberto J. (moraesg@usp.br) 
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 48
IS 11-12
PS 699-719
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 2
U2 13
AB Coconut is one of the main tropical crops. Aceria guerreronis Keifer
   (Eriophyidae) and Raoiella indica Hirst (Tenuipalpidae) are the main
   coconut mite pests in several African, American and Asian countries.
   Mites are not pests of coconut in Thailand. A survey was conducted in
   Thailand to determine the coconut mite fauna in search of prospective
   predators to control A.guerreronis and R.indica in other countries.
   Twenty-four species were found, including nine Mesostigmata, an order
   containing effective biological control agents. A few specimens of the
   mesostigmatid phytoseiids Neoseiulus baraki (Athias-Henriot) and
   Amblyseius largoensis (Muma), were associated with low populations of
   Colomerus novahebridensis Keifer (eriophyid occupying the same niche as
   A. guerreronis) and R. indica, respectively. A new mesostigmatid
   species, Lasioseius siamensis Silva and Moraes sp. nov.
   (Blattisociidae), is described. Complementary descriptions of
   Brontispalaelaps leveri Womersley and Neocypholaelaps ceylonicus Narita
   and Moraes (both Ameroseiidae), relatively abundant Mesostigmata, are
   provided based on collected specimens.
C1 de Moraes, Gilberto J.; Univ Sao Paulo, Dept Entomol & Acarol,
   Piracicaba, Brazil, Brazil.
EM moraesg@usp.br
RI de Moraes, Gilberto J./H-9849-2012; Narita, Joao Paulo/AAT-2596-2020
OI de Moraes, Gilberto J./0000-0002-5587-1781; 
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0022-2933
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Animals and man;
   Control; Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Associations; Ecology; Predators; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aceria guerreronis; Raoiella indica [Biological control /  / survey &
   systematics] [Arachnid predators / Mesostigmata / ] [Thailand / Bangkok
   / ]. 
   Lasioseius siamensis [Associations / Cocos nucifera (Plant) / New
   associate species] [Thailand /  / New species; plant associate]. 
   Mesostigmata [Biological control /  / predator survey & systematics]
   [Arachnid prey / Aceria guerreronis / ] [ / Raoiella indica / ]
   [Thailand / Bangkok / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Aceria guerreronis (Acari): [Prey].

   710].

   Associated with Cocos nucifera (Plant), p. 705].

TI Two new species of Esthemopsis C. Felder & R. Felder, 1865 (Lepidoptera:
   Riodinidae: Symmachiini) from southeastern and northeastern Brazil, with
   taxonomic comments on Esthemopsis teras (Stichel, 1910) stat. rev. and
   Esthemopsis pallida Lathy, 1932 stat. nov.
AU Silva Dias, Fernando Maia (fernandomsdias@yahoo.com.br) 
   Dolibaina, Diego Rodrigo
   Hendrik Mielke, Olaf Hermann
   Casagrande, Mirna Martins
SO Zootaxa
VL 3784
IS 2
PS 148-158
PD Mar 27 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of Esthemopsis C. Felder & R. Felder, 1865 from
   southeastern and northeastern Brazil are described, Esthemopsis sateri
   sp. nov. and Esthemopsis diamantina sp. nov., and revised and new
   combinations are proposed for Esthemopsis teras (Stichel, 1910) stat.
   rev. and Esthemopsis pallida Lathy, 1932 stat. nov., respectively.
   Lectotypes are designated for Lepricornis teras Stichel, 1910 and
   Esthemopsis caerulea pallida Lathy, 1932. The habitus of male and female
   specimens of the species discussed are illustrated; male head and labial
   palpus pictures, male and female genitalia illustrations are provided.

TI NEW SPECIES OF GENUS HERSILIA AUDOUIN, 1826 (ARANEAE: HERSILIIDAE) FROM
   INDIA.
AU Pravalikha, G.B.
   Srinivasulu, Chelmala (prava.gunti@gmail.com) 
   Srinivasulu, Bhargavi
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 6
IS 3
PS 5553-5557
PD Mar 26 2014
PY 2014
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Hersilia Audouin, 1826, Hersilia aadi sp.
   nov. is described from Andhra Pradesh, India with notes on the species
   known from India. The new species differs from its congeners based on
   having large palpal patella in males; and having two closely adjoining
   circular, small median genital openings and, long and curved copulatory
   duct in females.
